Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

We need your help to make sure that H.B. 6921, An Act Concerning Discrimination Based on a Person's Criminal History makes it through the Senate. Smart Justice has pushed the original bill as far as it can go this year, but we're not done. People should have these anti-discrimination protections, and we'll keep fighting for them.

Right now, Representative Robyn Porter has introduced an amendment to use H.B. 6921 to create the council on the Collateral Consequences of a Criminal Record, a group that could help generate a stronger bill that can go further next year. That amended bill passed the House of Representatives, and the Senate needs to act before midnight on Wednesday, or the bill will die.

Your state senator needs to hear from you: tell them to take action on HB 6921 today.

Connecticut will be safer, stronger, and fairer if our state protects people from being discriminated against solely based on their criminal record. If the amended version of H.B. 6921 passes into law, the council on the Collateral Consequences of Incarceration would be the first council mandated by Connecticut law to include justice-impacted people and organizations; would study ALL collateral consequences of incarceration; and would hold at least three forums in communities, not just at the Capitol.

Tell your state senator to vote yes for H.B. 6921.

Thanks for sticking with us,

Anderson Curtis, Gus Marks-Hamilton, and Sandy LoMonico
Smart Justice organizers, ACLU of Connecticut
